With beautiful visuals and a similar premise to the devastating Osama, this is a poignant animated film that doesn't shy away from its harrowing subject and yet is able to come up with a surprising amount of lightness in the fantasy stories that its protagonist always returns to.

I don't think I'm going out on a limb here when I say that the Taliban are a pack of shits. Slavishly devoted to a crooked reading of a religion they have no reason to believe is true, the more I hear about them the less I like them. And so when you set a story in a world that is controlled by these medieval-but-somehow-modern-day barbarians, and I get a sense that the story is a realistic one and it's unlikely that someone in tights and a cape isn't going to sweep down and punch them in their stupid faces, I get sad. It's not that a tough story set in a tough world can't make a good film, but for me it puts a ceiling on the enjoyment I can get from it, because any ray of hope is dashed by the knowledge that the characters, after whatever small victories they can find, will still be trapped under this cruel regime. And this film does a great job of finding those moments of happiness, and those people who will show true kindness, and the bleak backdrop serves to make these moments all the more precious and meaningful. But there was a part of me that always knew that this was the kind of film that wouldn't allow truly happy endings, for any of its characters. Having said that, the film is animated beautifully, the bonds it creates between its characters are genuine and warm, and the hardships are felt very keenly. It's a powerful film that serves as a powerful reminder that people are, at this very moment, living in terrible conditions dictated by terrible people. But I think it is possible to create that feeling and tell a more cohesive, less depressing story at the same time. As the film itself seems to tell us, stories can be a great way to escape from the horrors of the world. I'd have preferred it if this film had practiced what it preached a little more.

A culturally representational narrative simply demonstrates the strength of family love through rebellious survival in an irrational harsh society with unbelievable desperation of strict cruelty. While it is subtlety dark as a norm for the medium, it mostly satisfies with a strong yet fragile heart from the rich animation to graceful performances. (A-)

Visually stunning, 'The Breadwinner' is a beautifully animated film (the backgrounds and surroundings are really nice and transport you to another part of the world) that tells the story of a young girl who shows incredible courage in a world full of violence, hate and oppression. The atmosphere is very well captured and it does a good job of conveying the suffering and fear of the people under the rule of the Taliban. It's clear that the film has a certain message that it's trying to get across - humanising the people who are so often thought of as little more than "those guys in the Middle East who are killing each other" and showing the terrible effects of tyrannical rulers -- and it isn't interested in distracting from or complicating it. Regardless of whether or not you agree entirely with its portrayal of the circumstances, the story is undoubtedly inspiring, captivating and touching, and achieves exactly what it set out to do.

themselves.

Set against the ominous background of Western air-strikes looming above their heads, a young girl named Parvana has to dress as a boy in order to take care of her family under the repressive Taliban regime in Afghanistan after her father, the only adult male member of her family, is unjustly taken to prison. Deservedly Oscar nominated for Best Animated Feature, this Irish-Canadian production is unique and very affecting, as you will have to go back to 2007's Persepolis to find a film that tackles similar subject matter in such a mature, poetic and poignant manner. Even the story within the story that Parvana tells her baby brother has a revealing ending that packs an unexpected emotional punch. This film is about the beautiful art of storytelling as much as it is about the telling of these beautiful stories and director Nora Twomey and writer Anita Doron (adapting Deborah Ellis' book) deliver, with stylish flair and great aplomb, something emotionally rich and evocative, and moreover, an uncompromising ending that speaks volume about the horrendous and cruel situation they have to endure and close the film on a heartbreaking yet truthful note that is rare in live action films, and even more so for animation.
The Breadwinner is a beautifully animated narrative that consistently puts women at the center while depicting a harsh environment of violence controlled by men.

In regards of its visuals, the movie is beautiful and atunning, mixing storytelling with style and actual respect of its artistic roots, and even when Nora Twomey's direction focus on strong-mature subjects and themes, they manages to demonstrate a solid-yet-raw perspective on repression, submission and the hard situation towards the Islamic opressiom in the middle east, told in a unique-heartbreaking fashion.

it hurt to watch the way women were treated (btw, still are treated in some parts of the world), worse than animals - with so much hatred, cruelty, and disrespect. However, story of this brave girl is so inspiring with a strong empowering message. I enjoyed it so much!
A winning animated film that is serious enough to have been done live action.
Really puts stuff in to perspective. Also great animation.
Another perfect film from Cartoon Saloon.

Oscar-nominated film The Breadwinner tells the story of a young girl named Parvana (Saara Chaudry) who becomes the breadwinner of her family under terrible circumstances in which her father gets arrested, leaving no male relative in her family. Females aren't allowed to go out without males, so in order to help her family survive, she disguises herself as a boy. She reunites with her friend Shauzia (Soma Bhatia) who is also disguised as a boy to make money to get away from her abusive father. The movie is also set in a time when war has just started. What makes this film so beautiful is that it's so brutally honest. For example, we see women getting beaten up by men for going out in public without a man, and in Parvana's mother's case, her bruises are not hidden for the duration of the film. This is the most realistic animation I've ever watched. It doesn't hesitate to show elements that are normally hidden from children. Make note that this story is actually based on a children's novel. Throughout the movie, Parvana tells the story of a young boy who journeys to retrieve seeds from the evil Elephant King. This story encourages and inspires Parvana to keep going and also entertains her little brother Zaki. As young girls who have to take on hard labor, you don't hear them complain, but instead, you hear them dream. This is what makes the movie less heartbreaking and more hopeful. You can say this is a story very similar to Mulan minus the explicit message of "girls can do anything that boys can". I don't think the movie is necessarily meant to teach us something about gender discrimination, but rather to make us aware of some harsh realities. It's a risky move to produce this story in an animated format and not make it seem like everything is perfect in this world the way a Disney princess movie usually does.

"The Breadwinner" is a reminder that 2D animation can still be stunning as an art form. This movie is emotionally heavy all the way through and at times it even becomes pretty difficult to watch. It is ultimately a hopeful story but it certainly isn't always a pleasant one. The movie becomes aggressively sad at one point but it is set in a horrific society so it isn't surprising. It is a powerful and inspirational movie about going against the odds. The film is an overlooked gem from 2017 that is worth checking out, especially for fans of old-school animation.

As you may expect from the people behind Secret of Kells and Song of the Sea, this is an undeniably gorgeous animated film that stands out in the CGI-soaked modern landscape. It's also a quite important story worth telling...unfortunately, it's just never that fully engaging. While the emotions and drama are strong, the beats are fairly basic. Breadwinner is a passable character study that just never comes close to the heights of its other fantasy-realism brethren.
There is in this simple tale more honesty, beauty and understanding about what is really important in life, than in a 100 movies.
My kids are 4, 4, 8.  This movie sparked conversation between us about society.  Very stimulating visually as well as intellectually.
Engrossing story to go along with wonderful animation.
Stuff like this is why I want to do what I want to do with my life
The Breadwinner is a Poignant and beautiful film. I really enjoyed learning about the DIFFICULTIES of living in an traditionalist, islamic country. Recommended.
sad and heartwarming. visually stunning.
The Breadwinner insightful film into goings on in the middle east, portrayed in animation and done superbly.
Beautiful. I watched it 3 times and still love this amazing movie. A must see!!

A different way of life.  So this is about a young girl in Afghanistan who goes by the name Parvana (Saara Chaudry).  When her father is suddenly removed from the picture, her family is in a bit of a tough spot because of how radically different the culture treats women over there.  In order to simply walk the street, she disguises herself as a boy so she can provide for her family.  Now this was one that I was excited for, but I had no real means of watching this until after the fact.  It never even got a wide release, so I don't feel like this was really my fault.  At its peak, it was only at 38 theaters nationwide.  So, naturally, when I just happened to see it pop up on the Netflix streaming carousel, I jumped at the opportunity to watch it.  This is a stressful animated film that they have made here.  Now this is from the same studio that made The Secret of Kells, a beautiful little film that featured a tale that I never really got into.  This is not the case with The Breadwinner, and while it does feature the same gorgeous artwork, you are put on pins and needles for what is about to happen next.  It may be a cartoon, but it is a story where I never at any point felt safe for these characters.  You can't get higher stakes than survival, and over in Afghanistan, that is just the norm, and you learn to live with the constant danger of the Taliban.  It shouldn't come as much surprise to say that the way of life is different for women stateside when compared to Afghanistan, but Afghanistan is unique because they are viewed as different classes of people entirely.  These are men who hate women and are constantly ordering them around to the point of violence, and I felt like I easily grasped the message that this movie had to say: that is the status quo over there.  The whole time I watched this, my heart was in my throat, and I could see this ending poorly at any given moment.  It is just the type of movie it is, and I wouldn't have been surprised either way.  Because you are constantly on guard, you are on the edge of your seat throughout, and you are always engaged with the story at every single turn.  There is a great message of equality that is easy to get behind, and it gives you a good understanding of what exactly life is like in the Middle East.  This is a terrific little film that is well worth your time.
A moving, relevant film.  I joined Canadian Women for Afghan Women organization after seeing it.

An animated movie taking a much more adult approach than most, both in content and delivery, The Breadwinner will not be appreciated by general audiences for this very reason. It tackles its issues sensitively but without lamp shading, bravely but not gratuitously. The brutality is not graphic, but all the implications and consequences of it are very much present, making it impactful but not exploitative. The family dynamic is beautifully explored, as is the sexism and discrimination endemic to an entire culture. The animation occasionally looks clunky and awkward, especially when vehicles are involved, but mostly it's a startling departure from the norm, and the fantasy sequences, frequently cut to when the protagonists need a way to briefly digress from their difficult, mundane lives, are beautifully coloured and drawn, blending reality with childish fiction. The Breadwinner likely won't be remembered as it should be, and the mainstream will pass right over it to praise the likes of Coco, but it's a rare treat and isn't afraid to take risks where other animations wouldn't. Watch it as soon as you can.

The Breadwinner features gorgeous hand-drawn animation with some wonderful backgrounds and landscapes. The characterization is quite good and the overall story is moving, urgent in tone and quite powerful. The direction from Nora Twomey and the score are great as well. However, it did not reach greatness as it was seriously offset by its somewhat disappointing third act and annoyingly amateurish, mediocre voice acting.
I think the movie is good, but I think not all of this are correct.
A story of a girl in radical Afghanista that resembles Disney's Mulan in themes.

This movie was fantastic! The animations of it and the story was on point and it look like it was really real all the people who created and helped out with the movie is amazing keep it up lets see if you make The Breadwinner 2!!!
All I can say is that it is amazing, not predictable and enthralling..

This movie is an incredibly moving and disturbing look into what life was like living under the Taliban.  It is very well acted and animated with subtle moments where volumes of emotion are communicated in moments of silence countered with extreme moments of equal weight and power. 

However the one criticism I have is that this movie is NOT for children.  This is a very adult animated film and should not be marketed with what looks to be another "Disney Princess" in the movie poster.   I was about to watch this with my daughter before I read the description of it and then decided I would watch it by myself first to see if it was age appropriate. 

I am certainly glad I did because this film would potentially scar a young child as the film is filled with moments of violence and very adult subject matters that a child simply wouldn't understand. 

The PG-13 rating is very much deserved.  That being said for older audiences this is a very eye opening and impactful look into the lives of a culture that most of us barely understand.
Beautiful story with equally beautiful animation. This film moves the heart while opening the mind. The Breadwinner is a must see.
A beautiful film, with such depth and emotion I cannot recommend it more.
Beautifully animated and a wonderfully told story that addresses heavy topics ina gentle way for kids- without sugar coating it.

Not as sweet and charming as song of the sea but you wouldnt expect it to be with the subject matter,its a powerful movie and totally deserves its Oscar nomination

Woah,that was amazing for such a simply animated film. The hardships of being  a woman in some parts of the world are appalling and have no place in our modern world.

while different from the book, the film has great characters, stellar animation and the voice cast is very talented
Beautifully animated film also delivers a powerful story.

Impressive animation and a touching story about a young girl who is forced to pretend to be a boy to provide for her family after her father is arrested in 2001 era Afghanistan.  The characters and story grab you and the animation is good.. ending is a bit too abrupt for my tastes but its a good movie.

When we read (or watch) "The handmaid's tale" we call it dystopic, forgetting that in some part of our little planet the life's conditions are similar if not worse. Movies like these are part of the reminder, and they are always welcome. That being said: visually is very good, but the story miss some structure.
An important story beautifully told!
Proving that 2d animation still has a place in entertainment, Cartoon Saloon continues to impress with The Breadwinner, proving also that animation can be directed at a more mature audience.
a total delight, great great touching story

Subtle, yet to the point, 'The Breadwinner' puts itself out there and the reward is a movie that in engaging, honest and thought provoking. This is a movie that adults will enjoy as well as children. I took my 11-year-old daughter to see it, and we both enjoyed the story and animation. It's a tough film, in my ways, but I think it's important to expose kids to what's going on in the world. After the wall, I was careful to explain to her that while the Taliban were extremist Muslims, they do not represent all Muslims. An animated film shouldn't be too pedagogical, but I do think that any responsible adult taking a kid to this film should encourage intelligent conversation with your children about the topics the film engages. Films like this are so much better than the usual Disney dreck!

The Breadwinner is a good movie with a subject matter not commonly found in animated movies nowadays about an Afghanan girl forced to dress like a boy in order to rescue her father who was arrested in an unfair manner. This is obviously notThe Breadwinner is a good movie with a subject matter not commonly found in animated movies nowadays about an Afghanan girl forced to dress like a boy in order to rescue her father who was arrested in an unfair manner. This is obviously not aimed towards children and that's a good thing because they can have some dark moments without thinking that "it would be innappropriate for children".The Good:-The animation looks nice. This movie shows that 2D animation still has potential even in a CGI era of animation.-The dark subject matter this movie is about.-The dialogue was good for the most part.The Bad:-Maybe the fact that it gets a little repetitive during the second act and the ending is pretty predictable. Obviously it's still satisfying but after reading the premise before watching it I pretty much predicted the ending, and I was right.-I think some characters are underused. By that I mean that they could be a lot better developed if only they had more screen time and things to do.-The character design looked a little lighthearted for the tone this movie had, but I understand that's the art style from Cartoon Saloon.These are just little nitpicks I have and doesn't ruin the experience nor it changes my mind on this movie. It's not a terrible movie, it's not a bad movie, it's not an average movie and it's not a masterpiece either, it's a good movie that I actually enjoyed and I recommend it.

I always love Cartoon Saloon when it comes to their movies. While they only have (to date) three animated films, the Secret of Kells, Song of the Sea, and now the Breadwinner, they are one of the best animated studios making beautifulI always love Cartoon Saloon when it comes to their movies. While they only have (to date) three animated films, the Secret of Kells, Song of the Sea, and now the Breadwinner, they are one of the best animated studios making beautiful animation with unique character design, interesting and stimulating visual layouts of backgrounds and worlds, and constantly changing from styles and storytelling. For this film, the Breadwinner is the company's most political and arguably personal film. While the story is fictitious, as the original author interviewed refugees from Afghanistan to depict Taliban-era life, specifically for women who live during this patriarchal period, it will definitely resonate with anyone, largely female, who have been either oppressed or doubted. But really anyone can get behind the film's central character and family through hardship, happiness, triumphs, and sadness, and getting a perspective on another life!

Directed by Nora Twomey, the Breadwinner follows Parvana, an 11 year old Afghan girl who pretends to be a boy to provide for her family after her father was arrested by the Taliban. But instead of painting a black and white picture of Afghanistan, it takes the time to show the great aspects of the people and culture, but it doesn’t shy away from the ugliness that is prevalent throughout these countries. A relevant film to watch in this day and age, highly recommended.

rt_summary: Parvana is an 11-year-old girl who lives under Taliban rule in Afghanistan in 2001. After the wrongful arrest of her father, Parvana cuts off her hair and dresses like a boy to support her family. Working alongside a friend, she soon discovers a new world of freedom and danger. Drawing strength from the fantastical stories she invents, Parvana embarks on an epic quest to find her father and reunite her family.
